>So said Vladimir Bossicard on 4/7/2003 --------------------
<snip />
>> Ma=
ybe I change my opinion. But I am not so blind to overlook all the 
>> prob=
lems concerning JUnit/TDD.
>
>I don't say (and I think nobody says) that JU=
nit is perfect (why do
>you think I'm managing JUnit-addons?) but it gives =
you enough freedom
>to write and test pretty much whatever you want.  But o=
f course you
>have to invest some time understanding the framework.

Kent o=
nce told me about his vision of JUnit. He described a sign that JUnit was "=
doing its job": if each person that uses JUnit says, "I needed to add just =
one or two little things and JUnit was perfect for me," then JUnit has done=
 its job. Kent wanted to build the greatest possible intersection of all pe=
ople's needs; but remember that the more sets you intersect with, the small=
er the intersection...

>Since I haven't used JTest (well, $3500...) I can'=
t really say if
>JTest would be more useful *for me* than JUnit + my addons=
.  But I
>will first learn DbC before learning a new test runner (JTest).

=
That is a recommended course of action.
